shortTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

intermediateTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

longTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

msBullishSummary: CVS' diverse operations create the opportunity to view a patient more holistically by managing both medical and pharmacy benefits, which could lead to revenue and cost synergies for the organization.

The firm's entry into provider services has the potential to improve returns for all of CVS' segments if it can help patients more easily and cost-effectively manage chronic conditions through early intervention.
CVS' PBM remains an industry leader due to its intense focus on pharmaceutical cost trends that should continue to attract clients.
msBearishSummary: Healthcare reform will likely remain a recurring political topic until universal, affordable coverage is achieved in the U.S., and CVS' stock may experience volatility if scenarios that threaten its prospects gain traction.
Foot traffic at physical retail stores could continue to decline as consumers increasingly favor online retailers, like Amazon, creating the need to reinvent its retail store footprint's operations.
CVS' profit growth prospects appear lower than its managed care peers due to the challenges it faces in its retail operations.

researchReports.title: CVS Earnings: Weak Medicare Advantage Profits Cut Into 2024 Outlook and Fair Value Estimate
researchReports.summary: CVS Health offers a diverse set of healthcare services. Its roots are in its retail pharmacy operations, where it operates over 9,000 stores primarily in the U.S. CVS is also the largest pharmacy benefit manager (acquired through Caremark), processing over 2 billion adjusted claims annually. It also operates a top-tier health insurer (acquired through Aetna) where it serves about 26 million medical members. The company's recent acquisition of Oak Street adds primary care services to the mix, which could have significant synergies with all its existing business lines.

reports.reportTitle:
CVS Health Corp. operated 9,400 retail drugstores at the end of 2023, including over 1,880 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations is approximately 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, primary care centers and Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2023 revenue of $358 billion, with $187 billion in Health Services (which includes the PBM business), $117 billion in Pharmacy & Consumer Wellness (which includes the retail drug stores), and $106 billion in Health Care Benefits. Revenues exceed the total before elimination of transactions between segments which totaled approximately $52 billion. Aetna, was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated more than 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,675 retail drugstores at the end of 2022, including over 1,880 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2022 revenue of $322 billion, with about half in the PBM business (now Health Services), 34% in Retail/Long Term Care (Pharmacy & Consumer Wellness), and 27% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 77% of the $107 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 23% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CVS, PEAK, NFG, VSH, YUM, HA, DD, LIN
reports.reportTitle: Stocks gave up most of their early gains on Thursday morning as investors weighed earnings from Disney and PepsiCo, along with weekly employment data. Disney shares rose after the company reported better-than-expected fiscal 1Q results and announced substantial cost cuts, including the elimination of 7,000 jobs. The company is also likely to restore its dividend by the end of the year. PepsiCo shares rose following above-consensus 4Q earnings and the announcement of a 10% dividend hike. The Dow rose 0.3%, the S&P 0.3%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil fell 1% to $77.50 per barrel, while gold fell $6 to $1885 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: 517,000 New Jobs in January
reports.reportTitle: The U.S. economy generated 517,000 new jobs in January, far ahead of the consensus expectations and our forecast of 185,000. The unemployment rate declined slightly to a cycle-low 3.4%.  Average hourly earnings increased 10 cents month-to-month and are now 4.4% higher year-over-year, up 30 basis points month-to-month. Revisions to the jobs totals in the two prior months added 71,000 jobs to the economy. In January, jobs gains occurred in leisure and hospitality, professional and business services, government, and healthcare.  Industries notably absent from the outsize-jobs-gains during the month include mining, quarrying, oil and gas extraction, wholesale trade, and financial activities. December's jobs gains were revised to 260,000 from 223,000, suggesting the consumer segment of the economy may remain on a growth track for the next few months, despite the impact of the Federal Reserve rate hikes, the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and low consumer-confidence readings.  The news on the inflation front may not have been as sanguine as many investors wanted. While wage growth is easing, it remains strong. Stock futures have been in the red all morning, and turned even lower after the report was released as it signals the Federal Reserve may not be able to end their rate increases as soon as bulls hoped. The yield on the 10-year Treasury jumped to 3.5% from approximately 3.3% earlier this morning.

Sustainable Impact Investing, or ESG investing, is gaining traction not only with Argus Research clients but also with the global investment community. BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced in January 2020 that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,940 retail drugstores at the end of 2021, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2021 revenue of $292 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 76% of the $100 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 24% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,200 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Thursday morning, extending yesterday's Fed-driven selloff. On Wednesday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said that the central bank still had 'some ways to go' on rate hikes, and that interest rates at the end of the cycle could be higher than previously expected. The comments dashed investor hopes for a quick pivot to diminishing rate hikes. On the earnings front, Qualcomm shares fell sharply after the chipmaker issued much weaker than expected fiscal 1Q23 guidance, citing slower demand for smartphones. The Dow fell 0.5%, the S&P 0.6%, and the Nasdaq 0.5%. Crude oil fell 2% to $88 per barrel, while gold fell $24 to $1626 per ounce.

It also includes the director of research’s monthly investment strategy column, stock recommendations and sector picks, economic forecasts, and an asset allocation model. This month, the Focus List additions are Quanta Services, Inc. (PWR); Danaher Corp. (DHR); Expedia Group Inc (EXPE); EOG Resources, Inc. (EOG) and the Focus List deletions are Enbridge Inc (ENB); CVS Health Corp (CVS); Emerson Electric Co. (EMR); McDonald`s Corp (MCD).

Market Tries to Rally amid Softening Data

Sustainable Impact Investing, or ESG investing, is gaining traction not only with Argus Research clients but also with the global investment community. BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced in January 2020 that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

Markets have faced difficult times before, with challenging economic environments, wars, disease, banking and housing crises, and inflation much worse than we are seeing now, to name but a few. Of late, stock investors had it very good for a very long time -- but now, finding opportunities requires much more work. There is no secret sauce, but there are principals that are worth reviewing: 1) diversify; 2) look for strong management; 3) look for solid balance sheets; 4) do your homework; and 5) adapt. To assemble this week's list, we looked across several sectors that historically are considered to be the most-shielded from high inflation and high interest rates. We then cross-referenced our coverage universe for companies where our analysts recently raised target prices; that have an Argus Financial Strength rating of at least Medium-High; and that pay dividends of least 3%. Some companies also are featured in our model portfolios (Growth & Income, Equity Income, Growth, and Institutional). Here is our list of companies we believe to be recession-proof, all of which are rated BUY at Argus.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,940 retail drugstores at the end of 2021, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2021 revenue of $292 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 76% of the $100 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 24% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,200 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BKNG, CVS, FSLR, RJF, WY, HLT, NXPI
reports.reportTitle: Stocks plunged on Thursday morning, reversing Wednesday's strong Fed-driven rally. In his post-announcement press conference, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said that additional 50-basis-point rate hikes 'would be on the table,' but reassured investors that Fed officials were not discussing greater one-time hikes of 75 basis points. Mr. Powell acknowledged that inflation was 'much too high' and said that the Fed was 'moving expeditiously to bring it back down.' The Dow fell 2.6%, the S&P 3.0%, and the Nasdaq 4.1%. Crude oil rose more than 1% to $109 per barrel, while gold rose $20 to $1889 per ounce.

Our rating on the Healthcare sector is Over-Weight. Consumers are now more willing to spend on lifestyle enhancements along with necessary spending on life-saving treatments. In addition, the survival of the Affordable Care Act has kept the ranks of insured U.S. citizens above the historical average, further increasing consumer spending on healthcare services and products. Meanwhile, companies with experience in diagnostic testing, vaccines, and antiviral medicines, as well as suppliers of protective equipment and other hospital products, should benefit from efforts to contain the pandemic. The sector accounts for 13.7% of the S&P 500, and includes companies in the pharmaceuticals, medical devices, healthcare services, and insurance industries. The sector is outperforming the market thus far in 2022, with a gain of 1.3% through early April, while the S&P 500 has declined 6%. The following are examples of how we use our analysts' Healthcare sector ideas in our Focus List and Model Portfolios.  All stocks are rated BUY at Argus.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CVS, NOK, NOV, CHTR, ABBV, CARR
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Thursday morning following more signs of accelerating inflation. The Labor Department said that U.S. consumer prices rose at a 7.5% annualized rate in January, up from 7.0% in December. The reading exceeded the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 7.3% and was the highest since 1982. The core CPI excluding food and energy rose an annualized 6.0%, up from 5.5% in December. The Dow fell 0.2%, the S&P 0.3%, and the Nasdaq 0.3%. Crude oil rose more than 2% to $92 per barrel, while gold rose $5 to $1841 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Jobs Growth Strengthens in January
reports.reportTitle: The U.S. economy added 467,000 jobs in January, well above the consensus expectation of 150,000. Turning to other data points, the unemployment rate rose one-tenth of a percent to 4.0%, and the number of unemployed persons was up to 6.5 million from 6.3 million in December -- this as more people re-entered the work force. Average hourly earnings increased 23 cents month-to-month and are 5.7% higher year-over-year. Revisions to the two prior months added back a whopping 709,000 jobs to the economy, though we note the adjustments also reflect the Labor Department's annual benchmark process. In January, jobs gains occurred in leisure and hospitality, professional and business services, retail trade transportation and warehousing, construction, and manufacturing. The report (and especially the revisions) explains some inconsistencies to the December report that we highlighted last month and also indicates that the economy remains on a growth track -- even with the impact of the Omicron variant. The robust jobs numbers and high wage growth certainly feed into the narrative that the Federal Reserve will hike the fed funds rate at its March meeting.

On our five-year smoothed earnings figure (which is still depressed by the pandemic), stock prices (as expressed by the S&P 500) are well above the high end of our fair value range, which our model pegs at 4,200. Our stock-market valuation model takes into account factors such as stock prices, five-year normalized earnings (three historical years, including the sharp drop during the pandemic, and two forward-looking), GDP, inflation, and T-bond and T-bill yields. We note that stocks rarely trade right at fair value. Since 1960, on average, the index has traded at a relatively tight 2.5% above fair value, but the standard deviation to the mean is 16%. As such, we normally expect the S&P 500 to trade between 14% undervalued and 18% overvalued. At current prices, the stock market is about 50% above fair value, implying that investors may be overly optimistic about equities in the coming months. Though we are still bullish on the economy, earnings, and continued historically low interest rates, we'd feel better about the longer-term outlook for stocks if valuations were not so stretched. Several factors could improve valuations: a pullback in stock prices (seemingly underway and which occurred three times in 2021); lower bond yields; or better earnings, which we expect to see during the current reporting season.

Argus has published its latest Portfolio Selector, which features its popular Focus List. Each month, Director of Research Jim Kelleher, CFA, surveys the team of Argus Research industry analysts for their timeliest recommendations out of the company's fundamental universe of more than 500 stocks. The Focus List typically includes 30 stocks: turnover is high, as Director of Research Kelleher typically adds three or four new stocks per month. Below are the latest additions, all of which are rated BUY at Argus.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2020, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2020 revenue of $269 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 77% of the $91 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 23% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

Stocks were mixed on Thursday morning as investors digested employment data. The Labor Department reported that first-time jobless claims rose by 23,000 to 230,000, reflecting rising COVID cases. The Dow rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.04%, and the Nasdaq was down 0.6%. Crude oil traded above $82 per barrel, while gold fell $10 to $1817 per ounce.

Sustainable Impact Investing is gaining traction with the global investment community. In January 2020, BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Jobs Growth Picked Up in October
reports.reportTitle: As we expected, the U.S. economy improved in October and the number of new jobs created came in at 531,000. That's above the September total of 312,000, as the fourth wave of COVID-19 cases continues to ease. In other positive news, the unemployment rate dropped two-tenths of a percent to 4.6%; the change in total nonfarm payroll employment for August was revised up by 117,000 to 483,000; and September's total was increased by 118,000. The number of unemployed persons was down to 7.4 million in October -- still about 30% higher than the level prior to the pandemic. Nonfarm employment has increased by 18.2 million since a recent trough in April 2020 but is down by 4.2 million, or 3%, from its pre-pandemic level in February 2020. In October, job gains occurred in leisure and hospitality, professional and business services, manufacturing, construction, and retail. Looking ahead, we expect to see hiring remain strong due to the declining number of COVID-19 cases (the seven-day average is now 71k compared to 150k two months ago) as we head into the holiday season.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2020, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2020 revenue of $269 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 77% of the $91 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 23% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CTSH, CVS, HBAN, NOK, QCOM, RCL, DD
reports.reportTitle: Stocks were mixed on Thursday morning, a day after the Federal Reserve announced the start of its $15 billion per month tapering program. Fed Chair Jerome Powell also indicated that the Fed would prefer to wait for the completion of the tapering plan, and further improvement in the labor market, before considering higher interest rates. The Dow fell 0.2%, the S&P rose 0.3%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.6%. Crude oil rose slightly to $81 per barrel, while gold traded near $1796 per ounce.

Vickers Stock Research, a subsidiary of Argus Research Group, tracks insider trading and institutional ownership. Form 13-Fs have now come in from 2Q21.  We review the 13Fs of major activist investors, including Carl Icahn, Trian Fund Management, Jana Partners, and ValueAct Holdings, among others.  Activist investing has evolved in and is now less about generating a short-term return on an underpriced stock and more about achieving long-term returns through an active management/investor partnership.  Here are some recent new purchases and key holdings of Activist investors, according to Vickers.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2020, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2020 revenue of $269 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 77% of the $91 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 23% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BKNG, GOLD, CVS, HLF, HUBS
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Tuesday morning following weaker-than-expected July retail sales. The Commerce Department said that U.S. retail sales fell 1.1% last month, down from a gain of 0.7% in June and below the consensus forecast, which called for a decline of 0.3%. However, manufacturing data was positive. The Federal Reserve said that output at U.S. factories rose 1.4% in July, up from a decline of 0.3% in June and above the consensus forecast. The Dow fell 0.8%, the S&P 0.8%, and the Nasdaq 1.1%. Crude oil traded near $67.50 per barrel, while gold fell $7 to $1783 per ounce.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2020, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2020 revenue of $269 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 77% of the $91 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 23% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

Stocks fell sharply on Thursday morning, led by the Financial and Industrial sectors, amid concerns about the strength of the economic recovery and the impact of the Delta variant. On the employment front, the Labor Department said that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 373,000 for the week ended July 3, up slightly from 371,000 a week earlier and above the Bloomberg consensus of 350,000. Continuing claims fell to 3.339 million from 3.484 million a week earlier and came in below the consensus forecast. The Dow fell 1.4%, the S&P 1.4%, and the Nasdaq 1.6%. Crude oil fell slightly to $72 per barrel, while gold traded near $1806 per ounce.

The 1Q21 EPS season is mostly in the books, with retailers the last group to report over the next two weeks.  The results were impressive -- but came against an easy comparison with last year's 1Q, when the world started to shut down to fight COVID-19.  Through early May, Refinitiv reported that S&P 500 earnings rose 50.4% year over year -- the best quarter since 1Q2010.  Some 87% of companies have come in ahead of expectations, up from the prior four-quarter average of 76%, according to Refinitiv.  Where is the growth? Consumer Discretionary remains atop the list with a 170% earnings increase. Financials is second at 130%. Only Industrials is expected to remain negative -- with a 2% decline. Even the Energy sector, expected to have an earnings decrease at the start of the quarter, is now poised for 8% growth. Our analysts are always on the lookout for companies that raise their outlooks during earnings season. Management's ability to "raise guidance" can often be a catalyst for strong returns in the quarters ahead. Here are 20 BUY-rated companies in Argus coverage at which management has raised guidance or increased its outlook during the 1Q21 EPS reporting season.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose modestly on Wednesday morning, recovering some of their losses after Tuesday's selloff. On the employment front, payroll provider ADP said that U.S. private employers added 742,000 jobs in April, up from 565,000 in March. The reading was the strongest since last September but missed the Reuters consensus, which called for an increase of 800,000 jobs. The Institute for Supply Management said that its services index fell to 62.7 in April, down from 63.7 in March and below the consensus forecast of 64.3. The Dow rose 0.2%, the S&P 0.3%, and the Nasdaq 0.5%. Crude oil traded near $66 per barrel, while gold rose $7 to $1783 per ounce.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2020, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2020 revenue of $269 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. The 2019 and 2020 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

Sustainable Impact Investing is gaining traction with the global investment community. In January 2020, BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. But the performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as the climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks were largely flat on Wednesday morning as investors weighed mixed earnings reports and awaited the Federal Reserve's policy announcement this afternoon. Microsoft shares also fell despite better-than-expected sales and earnings. The Dow fell 0.3%, the S&P rose 0.1%, and the Nasdaq fell 0.2%. Crude oil traded near $64 per barrel, while gold fell $6 to $1773 per ounce.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Wednesday morning as investors weighed new retail sales and producer price data, and awaited the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting. The Commerce Department reported that U.S. retail sales rose a seasonally adjusted 5.3% in January, up from a decline of 1.0% in December and well above the Reuters consensus forecast of 1.1% growth. The Labor Department said that its producer price index rose 1.3% in January, up from 0.3% in December and the strongest gain since December 2009. The Dow fell 0.2%, the S&P 0.6%, and the Nasdaq 1.2%. Crude oil traded near $60 per barrel, while gold fell $18 to $1781 per ounce.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2019, including over 1,700 locations in Target stores. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2019 revenue of $257 billion, with about half in the PBM business, 30% in Retail/Long Term Care, and 20% in Health Care Benefits. Approximately 75% of the $87 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 25% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2019 results include Aetna, which was acquired at the end of 2018.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CVS, CVX, MNST, WMB, LYB, BABA, UBER
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rose strongly on Monday morning after Pfizer and BioNTech reported that their coronavirus vaccine was more than 90% effective in a late-stage clinical trial. The companies also said that they had thus far found no serious safety concerns with the vaccine. Pfizer shares rose nearly 9%. The Dow rose 3.9%, the S&P 2.8%, and the Nasdaq 0.7%. Crude oil jumped more than 8% to $40 per barrel, while gold dropped $88 to $1864 per ounce.

Sustainable Impact Investing is gaining traction with the global investment community. In January, BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $7 trillion in assets, announced that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. Mr. Fink's new focus follows rapid growth in sustainable assets in recent years. According to Opimas, a management consultancy focused on global capital markets, global assets under management in ESG strategies had grown to $40.5 trillion in 2020, doubling in four years and tripling in eight years. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies for various reasons. Now, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: CVS, CVX, FISV, RL, RHHBY, PSX
reports.reportTitle: Stocks were mixed on Monday morning as investors weighed new earnings reports and the details of President Trump's executive orders on coronavirus relief, which circumvent congressional authority and raise a range of legal and constitutional questions. The president's orders call for $400 per week in enhanced unemployment benefits, though these benefits would likely last for only a short period. Making the payments would also be logistically complex and require a $100 per week contribution from financially hard-pressed states. The Dow rose 0.9%, the S&P fell 0.1%, and the Nasdaq fell 0.9%. Crude oil traded near $42 per barrel, while gold rose $16 to $2044 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Dollar Hits New Highs
reports.reportTitle: The dollar has trended higher in 2020 and has now surpassed cycle highs set initially in 2001-2002 and then again in late 2016. On a real trade-weighted basis, the greenback currently is 10% above the average valuation over the past 20 years. The dollar rally reflects several factors, but primarily the relative strength of the U.S. economy and global investor confidence in the U.S. Federal Reserve and Department of Treasury as the world battles COVID-19. We anticipate a trading range around current levels for the greenback this year. That's because we think U.S. GDP may struggle to rebound -- not unlike the European and Asian industrialized economies. Congress is debating another round of fiscal stimulus, but there is no certainty that the divided government will once again reach agreement to help the economy. And, at some point, traders may become wary of the high level of US debt relative to GDP. Lastly, the lofty current valuation of the greenback implies that other currencies are likely undervalued, and traders can be expected to bid up those values over time.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BDX, HST, MSI, CVS
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Friday morning following a sharp drop in U.S. retail sales. The Commerce Department said that sales plunged 16.4% in April. This followed an 8.3% decline in March and exceeded the Reuters consensus forecast, which had called for a decline of 12.0%. Meanwhile, the House prepared to vote on a new $3 trillion relief package that would include direct support for state governments and additional payments to individuals; however, Senate Republicans have promised to reject the measure. The S&P fell 1.0%, the Dow 1.0%, and the Nasdaq 1.1%. Crude oil rose 4% to more than $28 per barrel, while gold rose $8 to $1749 per ounce.

Industries trading higher today include Multiline Retail, Biotechnology, and Internet & Direct Marketing Retail. Industries trading lower include Airlines, Energy Equipment & Services, and Consumer Finance. The VIX is up 0.38 at 41.20. The Dow fell 0.4%, the S&P rose 0.3%, and the Nasdaq rose 1.5%. Crude oil traded near $20 per barrel, while gold rose $11 to $1751 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The stock market ran out of gas very close to the initial resistance area of 2,650 on the S&P 500. The index basically retraced 38.2% of its decline very quickly -- in very similar fashion to the Fibonacci retracement of the major part of the crash in 1987, which started at the lower high on October 5. Sometimes, retracements work best when measured from a secondary peak or trough.

reports.reportTitle: The stock market ran out of gas very close to the initial resistance area of 2,650 on the S&P 500. Sustainable Impact Investing is gaining traction not only with Argus Research clients, but also with the global investment community. According to the Forum for Sustainable and Responsible Investment, global assets under management in the strategy have grown to $11.6 trillion in 2018 from $178 billion in 2005. The UN Principles for Responsible Investing -- to which Argus Research is a signatory -- now represents more than 1,750 signatories with assets of US$70 trillion, according to BMO Global Asset Management. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol and firearms. In time, the list of industries to avoid increased to include soft drinks, fast food, and oil and gas, among numerous others. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as the climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter and workers' rights.

In a volatile period for stocks, we saw increased demand for information from our website, www.ArgusResearch.com.  The most-popular reports are the stock-based Argus Analyst Reports, followed by the daily reports Market Watch, Market Digest and Market Movers. The daily reports contain, in addition to stock picks, information about the latest market and economic trends as well as Argus' forecasts. The homepage of our website also features updates and outlooks.  Here are the stocks in Argus' fundamental coverage that clients viewed the most in the month of November.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500's break above 3,000 is starting to look durable (knock on wood, quickly). The index first hit the 2,900s all the way back in August and September 2018. It then had a rough November and December, culminating in lows at 2,351 on 12/24/19.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500's break above 3,000 is starting to look durable (knock on wood, quickly). The index first hit the 2,900s all the way back in August and September 2018. It then had a rough November and December, culminating in lows at 2,351 on 12/24/19.

Consumer Staples stocks can be steady in times of market and economic volatility.  Case in point: amid the trade and tariff turmoil over the past six months, the Consumer Staples sector has outperformed the broad market by 270 basis points (a 9.0% return compared to 6.3% for the S&P 500), with a beta of 0.6. The sector accounts for 9.9% of the S&P 500, and includes Food, Beverage and Household Products companies, as well as Drug and Food retailers. We think investors should consider allocating approximately 7% of their diversified portfolios to the group.

Case in point: amid the trade and tariff turmoil over the past six months, the Consumer Staples sector has outperformed the broad market by 270 basis points (a 9.0% return compared to 6.3% for the S&P 500), with a beta of 0.6. The sector accounts for 9.9% of the S&P 500, and includes Food, Beverage and Household Products companies, as well as Drug and Food retailers. We think investors should consider allocating approximately 7% of their diversified portfolios to the group.

CVS Health Corp. operated 9,900 retail drugstores at the end of 2018, including over 1,600 locations in Target stores, and 42 locations in Brazil. The total number of locations exceeds 10,000 when we include a leading specialty pharmacy, Long Term Care pharmacies, Infusion Centers where cancer medicines, for example, are delivered through a needle. The combined company posted 2018 revenue of $195 billion, with more than half in the PBM business. Approximately 75% of the $84 billion in Retail and long-term care revenue came from prescriptions; 25% from over-the-counter medicines, Beauty and General Merchandise. The 2018 results include Aetna, which was part of the company for approximately one month.

CVS operated approximately 1,100 Minute Clinics, primarily within CVS pharmacy stores. The corporate headquarters is in Woonsocket, Rhode Island.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: SILK, LVS, VNO, AMAT, CVS
reports.reportTitle: Over a volatile five days, stock prices plunged early last week and then bounced back in the final two days of trading. While the net effect for the week was lower, the end-of-week push higher softened what seemed to be a developing broad correction. Looking forward, the average investor can be forgiven for feeling uncertain about the near-term path for equities. That said, corporate insiders, as we see it, are not average investors. So how did they react?

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: What is it about Monday in August? Last Monday, the S&P 500 was hit for almost 3%, and yesterday it was hit for another 1.2% -- the ninth straight day that the "500" has seen an intraday movement of at least 1%.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Despite all-time highs by major indices, market sentiment is a mystery -- with some readings very bullish (not good from a contrarian standpoint) and some quite bearish (a big plus). The five-day total P/C ratio is at 0.95 while the 30-day is at 0.90. During the advance since 2009, market trouble hasn't typically occurred until the five-day falls below 0.75 and 30-day is below 0.85 (sometimes 0.80).

reports.headHtml: Daily Spotlight: Forecast Trading Range for Dollar in 2H19
reports.reportTitle: The dollar continues to trend higher and is again approaching cycle highs set initially in 2001-2002 and then again in late 2016. Currently, on a trade-weighted basis, the greenback is 15% above the average valuation over the past 20 years. The dollar strength reflects several factors, including the Fed's now-completed rate-hike campaign and above-trend 1Q GDP growth in the U.S. -- not to mention global concerns over Brexit (which has not yet been resolved), economic weakness in Germany, and high debt levels in Italy. We anticipate a trading range around current levels for the greenback this year. That's because we think U.S. GDP will cool in the second half and the Federal Reserve will likely start to cut rates later this year. Meanwhile, we expect the uncertainty surrounding Brexit to be lifted later in October; the outcome may not be the best for the British, but they will at least know where they stand. Lastly, the lofty current valuation of the greenback implies that other currencies are likely undervalued, and traders can be expected to bid up those values over time.

Stocks rose on Thursday as muted inflation data boosted prospects for an interest rate cut from the Fed. The Labor Department said that import prices fell a greater-than-expected 0.3% in May, down from a revised 0.1% increase in April and the sharpest decline since December. Import prices also fell 1.5% from the prior year, compared to a 0.3% decline in April. On the employment front, first-time unemployment benefit claims rose by 3,000 to 222,000 for the week ended June 8. The Reuters consensus forecast had called for a slight decline to 216,000. The Dow rose 0.39%, the S&P 0.41%, and the Nasdaq 0.57%. Crude oil rose more than 2% following reports of attacks on two oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman. Gold rose $8 to $1345 per ounce.
